isis.stitle: ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CUMMINS CELECT - 1992 - 1993 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - ENGINE PROTECTION ANDDIAGNOSTIC SYSTEM

svcprocinfo.para: Refer to appropriate circuit diagrams, located in this section, for the following discussions.

svcsubproc.title: Standard Engine Protection System
svcsubproc.para: CELECT engines are equipped with an engine protection system as a standard feature. This system monitors important engine parameters and logs diagnostic faults when an over- or under-normal operating range condition occurs. The engine protection also derates engine torque and engine speed when certain engine fluid parameters pass a limit point.
All CELECT engines monitor the following five inputs:
* CUMMINS-installed components.
** International-installed component.

If any of the above sensors signals conditions outside limits pre-set by CUMMINS, the oil/water warning light will begin to flash and the engine will be gradually derated. If the out-of-specification condition returns to acceptable limits, the light will turn off, and the fault may be logged as an inactive fault in the ECM.

svcsubproc.title: OPTIONAL ENGINE SHUTDOWN FEATURE
svcsubproc.para: This feature is optional and must be selected by the customer. The engine protection shutdown is triggered when the engine protection lamp starts flashing for the current engine protection/warning derate. Once triggered, the engine will shut down after 30 seconds. During the 30 second warning period, the standard torque and speed derates will occur. The engine can be restarted by cycling the key switch. After the engine is restarted, it will be limited to the maximum torque and/or speed derate levels of the out-of-range parameter if the engine protection fault is still active.
All CELECT systems have three warning lights located in the instrument panel. Each Celect system includes a standard engine protection system to prevent engine damage.

svcsubproc.title: "YELLOW" OIL/WATER WARNING LIGHT
svcsubproc.para: The yellow oil/water warning light is located in the right gauge cluster and alerts the driver of the following conditions:

step1.para: Low or High engine oil pressure

svcsubproc.para: If any of previous conditions goes outside the limits pre-set by CUMMINS, the engine will be gradually derated to protect the engine. If the CELECT system is derating the engine, the "yellow" oil/water warning light will illuminate. When the condition returns to acceptable limits, the light will turn off.

The oil/water warning light receives 12V ignition power (key on) from fuse F6. The oil/water warning light ground circuit, 97AZ, goes to ECM terminal #1. The ECM opens or closes the ground, turning the warning light off or on in response to engine conditions.

svcsubproc.title: "YELLOW" ENGINE WARNING LIGHT
svcsubproc.para: The "yellow" engine warning light comes on each time the key switch is turned to the ON position and will remain on for several seconds as a system self-test, then turn off. If the warning light remains ON, it means that the ECM has detected a problem. A "yellow" warning light means that the vehicle can be driven safely, but the fault must be corrected as soon as possible.

The "yellow" engine warning light receives 12V ignition power (key on) from fuse F6. The ground circuit for this light is circuit 97AT to the ECM at pin #25. The ECM opens or closes the ground circuit, turning the warning light off or on in response to engine conditions.

svcsubproc.title: "RED" ENGINE STOP LIGHT
svcsubproc.para: The "red" engine stop light comes on each time the key switch is turned to the ON position and remains on for several seconds as a system self-test, then turns off. If the "red" engine stop light remains ON, the vehicle must be parked as long as the fault remains.

The engine stop light receives 12V ignition power (key on) from fuse F6. The warning light ground circuit (97AP) goes to the ECM at pin #16. The ECM opens and closes the ground circuit turning the warning light off or on in response to engine conditions.

svcsubproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC CONNECTOR (313)
svcsubproc.para: The 8-pin diagnostic connector utilizes four circuits as follows:

step1.para: Pin 1, circuit 98A(+), is the positive Data Link connection through J5 (red Data Link connector) to the ECM (terminal 27).
Pin 2, circuit 98C(-), is the negative Data Link connection through J6 (blue Data Link connector) to the ECM (terminal 5).
Pin 3, circuit 97DL/97D, is 12V ignition feed from 5 fuse F5. Power is available with the key switch in the ON position.
Pin 5, circuit 11-GL, is grounded to the cab.

svcsubproc.title: DIAGNOSTIC ON/OFF SWITCH (83)
svcsubproc.para: The diagnostic on/off switch receives a 5V signal (circuit 97AN(5V)) from ECM pin #10. Closing the switch applies 5V to the ECM at terminal 21. This tells the ECM that the diagnostic ON/OFF switch has been turned to the ON position.

svcsubproc.title: IDLE/DIAGNOSTIC INC/DEC SWITCH (348)
svcsubproc.para: The low engine idle speed (rpm) can be adjusted with a two-position momentary, increment/decrement switch. This function permits the operator to adjust idle speed up or down in units of 25 rpm by toggling the switch. Maximum idle speed is 800 rpm and minimum idle speed is 550 rpm. When the idle has been changed and the key turned OFF, the new setting is saved in memory. This feature is owner selected and can be turned OFF with a Compulink TM adjustment.

A 5V signal from the ECM is present at the switch (circuit 97AX(5V)). Momentarily placing the switch increment position or decrement position applies the 5 volts to the ECM at terminal #14 or terminal #23. This causes the engine idle rpm to be increased or decreased in 25 rpm increments.

svcsubproc.title: RADIATOR COOLANT LEVEL SENSOR (342)
svcsubproc.para: The Coolant Level Sensor sends coolant level data to the ECM for the engine protection system. The Coolant Level Sensor connects to the International engine harness at connector (342). The ECM communicates using the coolant sensor with four circuits.

The four circuits are part of the International engine harness and connect the Low Coolant Level Sensor to the ECM through the Cummins 9-way connector (312). The sensor contains a printed circuit board which should not be tested with a volt-ohm meter.
The Coolant Level Sensor receives a 5 volt signal on circuit 34B (5V) from connector (312).
When the coolant level is above the probe, circuit 34A will send a high signal (3.5 volts minimum) to the ECM and circuit 34 will send a low signal (0.5 volt maximum) to the ECM.
When the coolant level is below the probe, circuit 34 will send a high signal (3.5 volts minimum) and circuit 34A will send a low signal (0.5 volts maximum) to the ECM.
